title: Kansas Sets Highway Issue
description: The Kansas Department of Transportation is offering $250 million of tax exempt highway revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 5.6 percent for an issue due in 2013 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were offered at prices to yield from 4.45 percent in 1999 to 5 percent in 2003, 5.45 percent in 2088 and 5.55 percent in 2010. Underwriters said the bond offering was rated double-A by Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Fitch Investors Service.

description: The Colombian Government's campaign against drug traffickers has suffered a setback after a high court declared that the chief prosecutor's policy of promising reduced sentences to informers with criminal records was unconstitutional.

description: A rotund player kept the Phoenix Suns alive tonight -- and it was not Charles Barkley. Oliver Miller, a 300-pound rookie from Arkansas who spent part of this season popping diet pills, was an unexpected force tonight in the Suns' 107-102 playoff victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Strike in Eastern Germany: Economics and Anger
description: Traffic is backed up at the entrance of the Stahl und Walzwerk Brandenburg G.m.b.H. steel mill, which has been sealed off by a new shift of determined pickets. As drivers complain and tempers on both sides rise, a union official rushes from strike headquarters next door and tells his men it is illegal to block the gate. Grudgingly, they let cars and trucks through.

And ease is the name of the game.

title: Public & Private; The Rescuers
description: When the word went out among the good people of occupied Copenhagen that the Germans were preparing to round up their Jewish neighbors, Jorgen Kieler was a 23-year-old medical student working with the resistance. In the space of two days, he and his friends helped organize 13 fishing boats, "our little fleet," that carried more than 800 Jews to Sweden and safety.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 NO IMMEDIATE ACTION ON BOSNIA Even if Bosnian Serbs reject a peace plan anew, there will be no immediate military response from the United States. The Administration seems certain that the plan will be approved, but less sure that any pact will end the fighting. A1 A CHANGE IN PLANS? Secretary of State Warren Christopher and French leaders agreed to send United Nations peacekeepers to Bosnia quickly if the Bosnian Serbs prove they are serious about a peace plan, but he acknowledged that more consultations will be necessary and that the United States may have to modify its plan. title: Thorkild Jacobsen, Scholar, Dies at 88; Wrote of Cuneiform
description: Thorkild Jacobsen, an archeologist who was an expert on Sumerian tablets and conducted excavations in Iraq, died Sunday at a hospital in Lebanon, N.H. He was 88 and lived in Bradford, N.H.

title: A New Designer At Anne Klein
description: THERE is no more dramatic sign of the changing point of view of American sportswear than Richard Tyler's being named yesterday to replace Louis Dell'Olio as the designer at Anne Klein & Company. While both are the same age -- 44 -- Mr. Tyler is a West Coast designer, tanned and with wavy rock-star hair, and has developed a young Hollywood clientele. Mr. Dell'Olio is a child of Seventh Avenue, beginning his career at 24 at Anne Klein, working alongside Donna Karan until she left to start her own house.

title: Review/Television; Opinions on Pornography: Pro, Con and a Bit of Each
description: To say that "Patently Offensive: Porn Under Siege" is even-handed is a gross understatement. This program has more hands than a sexy Indian deity and distributes pronouncements, from First Amendment absolutism to calls for censorship, like alms. The arguments find academics cheek to cheek with flesh peddlers and religious rightists in bed with radical feminists.

title: Reno Moving to Reverse Stiff Sentencing Rule for Minor Drug Crimes

title: Boyfriend of One Victim Is Charged in 6 Slayings
description: An angry boyfriend stabbed Maria Rodriguez to death after an argument in her East Harlem apartment on Saturday, the police said yesterday. Then, they said, he bludgeoned, strangled and stabbed her three children and her mother, slept overnight in the blood-drenched apartment, went to a Yankees baseball game and finally killed her mother's companion the next day.

title: Bosnia's Serbs Weigh a Familiar Choice
description: The Bosnian Serbs' parliament, a self-proclaimed assembly of ardent nationalists, militia leaders and local political bosses, is to make a choice on Wednesday that could make the difference between peace in the Balkans or prolonged war.

title: Sports of The Times; Dale Hunter Could Have Missed Year
description: IF it had been up to me, Dale Hunter would be up in Ontario right now, winterizing his cabin for his year's sabbatical from hockey. How do I know he's got a cabin up in Ontario? He must. All hockey players have cabins in Ontario. It's where they go when the season ends.

title: Seles Ready to Discuss Her Treatment
description: MONICA SELES will talk to reporters today about her treatment for the stab wound inflicted by a spectator at a German tournament. IMG, the Cleveland company that manages Seles, announced the news conference yesterday at the Italian Open.

title: Lobbyists' Gifts To Be Disclosed, Senators Agree
description: The Senate succumbed today to ethical bombardment by a Minnesota Democrat and voted to bare one of its most tightly held secrets: the size and worth of the gifts, free meals and other perks showered on its members by lobbyists.

description: Being a Roman Catholic priest is increasingly uncomfortable. As a group, our image suffers as we endure what seem to be weekly disclosures that yet more clerics have engaged in sexual activity ranging from standard lust to outright perversion.

title: Review/Music; A Requiem for a Russian
description: Matthew Greenbaum's "Requiem for Vladimir Mayakovsky" -- the piece that ended Friday's mostly literary, partly musical centennial celebration of that Russian poet's birth -- provided an unwitting metaphor for the event as a whole. Half buried in its electronic moans and swirls lay the tinny recorded voice of Mayakovsky himself, deliberately muffled and distorted and offering the impression of a suppressed personality wanting to be let out.

title: When Designers Get the Giggles
description: FOR the last few years one has come to expect the wittiest tabletop designs from Alessi. This year, the mood is even more lighthearted. Especially fun are Alejandro Ruiz's extraterrestrial creature-like salt and pepper shakers; and Massimo Morozzi's bottle opener, shaped like a baby rattle, above, in black, white, or baby blue or pink. Of course.

title: Art Imitates Furniture
description: ON view at the Design Gallery Milano was Alessandro Mendini's latest collection of artifacts. (Somehow it doesn't seem appropriate to call a chest of drawers that looks like a stack of boxes and is crowned with a bonsai tree, below, or cabinets topped with glass fish, simply "furniture.") Even those visitors who claimed to be tired of art furniture could not help be charmed by what they saw.

title: INFECTION LINKED TO TAINTED CIDER
description: A study published today has documented an outbreak of bacterial infection in southeastern Massachusetts caused by fresh-pressed apple cider.

title: Bronx Hospital Is Criticized Over Hazards
description: A routine inspection of North Central Bronx Hospital this winter found a variety of problems that threaten patient care, according to a report released yesterday by the New York State Department of Health.

title: Burlington Coat Factory reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Included a gain of $ 601,000, or 2 cents a share, on the adoption of SFAS 109, a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Reviews/Television; A Movie Queen and Her Serious Side
description: This year's recipient of the American Film Institute Award for Life Achievement, bestowed on March 11 at a dinner in Beverly Hills, Calif., is Elizabeth Taylor. As might be expected, she puts her own distinctive spin on the occasion, now condensed to a one-hour tape that can be seen on ABC tonight at 9 as "The American Film Institute Salute to Elizabeth Taylor."

title: Money Market Fund Yields Change Slightly in Week
description: Yields offered on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week, with little movement in either direction.

description: b-Net loss, which included loss of $ 3,122,000 related to costs, expenses and interest income resulting from company's Chapter 11 reorganization.Interco implemented its reorganization plan in August 1992, and changed from a fiscal year ended in February to a calendar year as of Jan 1, 1993.

title: Hornets Oust Celtics In Down-to-Wire Style
description: The embattled Boston Celtics, already reeling from the potentially career-ending heart condition of Reggie Lewis, suffered a final, bitter defeat of their season when Charlotte's 104-103 victory gave the Hornets a three-games-to-one triumph in the franchise's first playoff series.

title: Horsham Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $ 3.3 million from the Copper Mountain ski resort, which was sold in December 1992.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Finally Wins One on Clay After struggling on clay all season, Boris Becker finally won on that surface yesterday when he beat Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 6-2, in the $1.7 million German Open in Hamburg. Top-seeded Stefan Edberg, fresh from Sunday's tournament victory in Madrid, also breezed into the third round by eliminating Marcelino Filippini of Uruguay, 6-3, 6-3. Ivan Lendl, seeded No. 3, also reached the third round by edging Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 6-2, 0-6, 6-2. The Olympic champion, Marc Rosset of Switzerland, was forced to withdraw from his second-round match against Francisco Clavet of Spain because of tonsillitis. (AP) A Day for Teen-Agers: Jennifer Capriati overcame an aching elbow and more than 20 unforced errors and beat Sandra Cecchini, Italy's top female player, 6-3, 6-2, in the Italian Open in Rome. But the 17-year-old American had to take runner-up honors for the day's thrills to Francesca Bentivoglio, a 16-year-old qualifier from Italy. Cheered on by a large center court crowd at the Foro Italico, Bentivoglio upset seventh-seeded Jana Novotna, 7-5, 7-6 (7-5). The victory by the youngster, ranked 329th in the world, kept alive Italy's slim hopes in the clay-court classic, which has not been won by an Italian since Raffaela Reggi in 1985. (AP)

title: Essay; What About Weld?
description: Republican William F. Weld, successor to Michael Dukakis as Governor of Massachusetts, is building a record in office that should be a conservative's dream:

title: F.C.C. Asked To Deny Bid To Buy Post
description: In the first of what is expected to be a series of efforts to stop Rupert Murdoch's attempt to buy The New York Post, a Connecticut businessman who bid for the paper in March asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to block the acquisition.

Basketball Colleagues at Memorial for Valvano
description: It was planned as a sort of second-chance service, to give Jim Valvano's New York friends who could not make the funeral in North Carolina an opportunity to pay their respects to the former North Carolina State basketball coach turned broadcaster who died of cancer last week at 47.

title: An Old Florio Aide Returns But Is Haunted by Inquiry
description: Joseph C. Salema, Gov. Jim Florio's old friend, most trusted aide and all-purpose chief adviser, seems to find himself in a recurring bad dream: He rushes to help his friend and instead threatens him with scandal.

description: Boxwood Background

title: D'Amato Jury Ends Day of Deliberations
description: The jury in the mail-fraud trial of Armand P. D'Amato, the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, concluded its second day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict.

title: Energy Dept. Submits To Oversight on Safety
description: After years of resisting any control over it by other Federal agencies, the Energy Department said yesterday that it would voluntarily submit to supervision of worker safety by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, among other steps to improve safety.

title: An Exhibition of Indian Quilts Inspired by the Morning Star
description: In the 19th century, when the buffalo began to disappear from the Northern Plains, the Indians lost the animal whose meat they ate, whose sinews they used as thread, and whose hide they turned into robes and used to wrap around themselves and to shroud the dead. In place of buffalo robes, the Indians made quilts.

title: NORTH KOREA STIRS NEW A-ARMS FEARS
description: Experts monitoring North Korea say they are increasingly concerned that the country may be preparing to use 50 tons of uranium now fueling a large reactor as raw material for nuclear weapons.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
ITT Selling A Troubled Pool of Loans
description: The ITT Corporation moved a step closer to alleviating a huge financial headache yesterday by tentatively agreeing to sell a subsidiary's troubled $2.18 billion unsecured consumer loan portfolio to a group of investors.

title: Altering A Kahn: Protest Widens
description: A two-year campaign to protest construction of an addition to the Salk Institute for Biological Sciences, the landmark building in La Jolla, Calif., designed by Louis I. Kahn, reached a new stage yesterday, as the institute's head, Dr. Brian Henderson, said through a spokesman that he would not meet with an advisory committee of distinguished architects that includes Philip Johnson, Frank Gehry, James Ingo Freed, Kevin Roche, Robert Venturi and Richard Meier.

title: General Re Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 61 million, or 70 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.General Re said that its earnings for the latest quarter included after-tax realized capital gains of 42 cents a share, compared with 35 cents a share, in the year-ago period.

title: Review/Dance; Looking Deceptively Simple Inside Stage Frames
description: Trisha Brown can be trusted not to do anything the easy way these days. "One Story as in Falling," a premiere presented by the Trisha Brown Dance Company on Tuesday night at City Center, is a case in point. There is that mysterious title, for one thing. And the dance is built around a 16-minute phrase of movement that the choreographer then re-used in "Another Story as in Falling," a hit of this Brown season.

title: U.S. Can Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 3,402,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 12,537,000 from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.The results included charges from warrant accretion equaled to 4 cents a share in the latest first quarter and 6 cents a share in the year-ago period.

title: Critic's Notebook; Inspiring Compassion, if Not Action
description: Most of the maunderings committed on the subject of television imagery have focused hard on its power to influence policy. It was assumed that the impact of the stunning scenes from China, Romania, Somalia, Los Angeles on so many millions of Americans must make itself felt in pressure on Washington to do something decisive to relieve the victims and punish the perpetrators. Whether that should be a source of satisfaction or concern was less obvious.

title: Barcelona Reclaims Miro, An Expatriate Native Son, With Centenary Exhibitions
description: Joan Miro was born here 100 years ago, but he spent most of the 1920's and 30's in Paris and then settled in Palma, Majorca, where he died in 1983. Indeed, until he established the Joan Miro Foundation in Montjuic Park overlooking this city in 1975, Barcelona had few of his works.

title: In Italy, the Tray's the Thing
description: THE exhibition of "Trays by Fornasetti" was one of the not-to-be-missed stops at the Salone del Complemento d'Arredo, the accessories show that accompanied Milan's annual furniture fair. The trays, covered with the prolific Piero Fornasetti's inimitable graphics, look fresher than ever before.

title: Theater in Review
description: Buya Africa John Houseman Theater 450 West 42d Street Clinton Musical director, Emma; musician, Valerie Naranjo; stage manager, Margo Barkdall; house manager, Robert Meyer. Presented by Eric Krebs Theatrical Management. WITH: Thuli Dumakude.

title: W. J. Dorvillier, 85; Founded Newspaper And Won a Pulitzer
description: William J. Dorvillier, founder, editor and publisher of The San Juan Star, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1961 for distinguished editorial writing, died yesterday at Concord Hospital in New Hampshire. He was 85 and lived in Concord.

title: Big Brother and the Computer Age
description: Can the nation trust its secrets to its spies?

title: OWENS-CORNING PLANS CHANGES IN EUROPE GROUP
description: Citing weak market conditions in Europe, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs at its industrial materials group in Europe and spend $110 million to expand the group's capacity by 25 percent. Owens-Corning said the changes were being made to "surmount the adverse market conditions in Europe." The industrial materials group makes reinforcements, yarns and resins, which are used as alternatives to steel. Additionally, the concern said it would close its Falkenberg, Sweden, manufacturing plant, centralize many administrative services and create a central customer service center. The 500 jobs to be cut represent about 20 percent of the group's European work force, Owens-Corning said.

title: Montross Heads Team USA Lineup
description: ERIC MONTROSS of North Carolina heads a team of 12 college players selected yesterday to Team USA, which will represent the United States in international competition. CHRIS WEBBER of Michigan was also selected, but three hours after the team was announced, the all-America sophomore announced he was giving up the remainder of his college eligibility to make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft. That automatically dropped him from the team.

title: Starbucks Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding reflected the pro forma conversion of preferred stock and warrants into common stock, which occurred at the completion of the company's public offering in June 1992.

Sunrise Medical Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Now Bowie Goes Out and Nets May Soon Be Following
description: Chuck Daly might as well park an ambulance near the court at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and leave the back door open. Sooner or later someone on the Nets will need medical attention. Daly himself must have got an ulcer tonight when center Sam Bowie was helped off the court with a sprained left ankle. Another injury, another loss, this time by 93-84 to the Cleveland Cavaliers in Game 3 of their playoff series.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT MacNEIL, executive editor and co-anchor of "The MacNeil/ Lehrer Newshour," has been elected chairman of the board of the MacDowell Colony, the 86-year-old artists' and writers' retreat in Peterborough, N.H.

title: Fed Cites Improvement In Economy for April
description: The Federal Reserve said today that there was "generally modest improvement" in the economy in April after the storm-related slowdown in much of the country in March.

title: Golden Names of Earlier Era Begin Masters Tournament
description: Owen Williams built it -- a tidy tennis arena within an old armory -- and they came, in modest numbers.

title: Du Pont, Struggling With Costs, Revamps Units
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which has struggled to cut costs, yesterday announced a reorganization of its chemical and manufacturing operations that would further reduce employment and, if it worked as planned, speed decision-making.

title: A Closed Shop Is Remembered
description: Although Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver of New York has been closed for a year and a half and many of its staff have moved on to other shops, the once-hot agency is seeking former employees to attend a second annual reunion. The event is scheduled to begin at 6 tonight at the Art Directors Club, 250 Park Avenue South, Manhattan. The agency was closed in November 1991 by its parent, Grey Advertising Inc., after the loss of key accounts, like Subaru of America Inc.

title: U.S. to Use Agents to Detect Mortgage Bias
description: The Clinton Administration, granting a wish long held by consumer groups and housing activists, has decided to begin the widespread use of undercover agents to test whether mortgage lenders are illegally discriminating among borrowers.

title: Kodak Chief Wins Support of Key Investor
description: The chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company received some limited support yesterday from an important investor, the California Public Employees Retirement System.

title: Clinton Again Delays Announcing His Campaign-Finance Plan
description: Still struggling to win Congressional support for President Clinton's campaign-finance package, the White House today put off announcing the measure, at the request of House Democrats who wanted more time to negotiate over the proposal.

title: Pacers Are Impressed, but Not Overly So
description: Asked for his impression of the Knicks after Game 3, Donnie Walsh, the Pacers' general manager, did not mince words.

title: New York Times Revamps Management in Advertising
description: The New York Times announced a reorganization of its advertising department yesterday, naming three executives of The New York Times Company as vice presidents for advertising. Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of the newspaper, said the appointments would be effective June 1.

title: Romeo Gigli's Couture Rugs
description: ROMEO GIGLI, the Italian fashion designer, thought up the idea for his own line of kilim rugs while on vacation last year on a Greek island, said Christopher Farr, director of a London-based rug company. "He based them on his primeval feelings on the creation of the universe," Mr. Farr added.

title: Bridge
description: Ask an average player, or even an expert, to define a nonmaterial squeeze and you will probably collect a blank stare. One of these rare supernatural birds, first analyzed by the late Geza Ottlik of Hungary, occurred two weeks ago. It was played in the Thursday night Imp Pairs game at the Town Club, 9 East 86th Street in Manhattan, which has one of the country's busiest rubber bridge programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator John S. McCain referred incorrectly to the end of the Vietnam War, in which he served and was a prisoner of war. It was in April 1975; what occurred in January 1973 was the cease-fire agreement.

title: MCI WINS 5-YEAR CONTRACT WITH J. P. MORGAN
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had won a five-year, $80 million contract to manage part of the worldwide telecommunications systems of J. P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company. MCI edged out both the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and BT P.L.C. for the global award, although both competitors retain other parts of the bank's telecommunications business. Beginning June 1, MCI will manage almost all the bank's voice, data and video communications services in 20 locations in all continents except Africa.

title: Another Outsider Is Appointed at I.B.M.

description: Most residents in Onondaga County do not remember when people could fish and swim in Onondaga Lake. Helen Bailey, 71, does.

description: The Devils have signed a three-year agreement with Capital District of the American Hockey League to become New Jersey's top affiliate in the minor leagues. The Devils said they would supply the players and the coaching staff for Capital District, which was the Islanders' top affiliate for the past two seasons.

title: Economic Scene; Group of 7 Nations: Suddenly Pals, But Can They Coordinate?
description: DID the finance ministers of the industrial powers really have nothing to squabble about at their meeting in Washington last week -- or did someone spike the punch bowl with LSD? title: A Livery-Cab Driver Refuses to Be Robbed
description: Jorge Francia, who had emigrated from Peru and had ended up driving a livery cab 14 hours a day to support his family, felt the barrel of the gun against his neck early yesterday morning in Queens.

title: Doctor Held In a Sex Case Had a Record
description: A doctor who was arrested and charged yesterday with fondling a patient in an Upper East Side medical office was permitted to practice medicine in New York State even though state regulators knew that he had been convicted of sexually assaulting a patient in New Jersey four months ago.

description: In findings expected to alter the direction of cancer research, scientists have discovered the existence and are near to pinpointing the location of a gene that causes several major cancers, and they have discovered a new way that aberrant genes cause the disease.

description: For the first time since the Federal Government began regulating the safety of the American food supply, the Department of Agriculture announced yesterday that it would require all raw meat and poultry to have labels with cooking and handling instructions.

description: Democratic members of the Legislature elected H. Carl McCall as New York's State Comptroller today, but the Republican lawmakers who boycotted the process filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the vote.

title: Clinton's Refocusing
description: When President Clinton confessed on Tuesday that the White House needed "tighter coordination" because it had lost clarity of purpose, he said he planned to fix things by reorganizing his staff. It may take more than that.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BSN S.A., Paris, has bought 100 percent control of Aliments Delisle Ltd., a Canadian yogurt manufacturer. Terms were not disclosed. BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO., New York, said it had bought natural gas producing wells in the Arkoma Basin of Arkansas from Exxon Corp. for $20 million.

description: For the second consecutive year, Chiat/Day of New York has taken top honors at the annual Obie Awards show, sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America's marketing division.

title: Clinicom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the strangulation of a 24-year-old woman at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in midtown Manhattan included an erroneous occupation for the suspect, Gerald Ardito, supplied by the police. He was working for Creative Network Systems at the time of his arrest. He is not the owner of Prompt Temporary Agency.

title: Squaring Off on Taxes; Clinton Proposals Are Drawing Fire From Supporters of 1986 Reform Law
description: As Congress takes up the President's tax plan in earnest this week, the Clinton proposals are coming under fire from many supporters of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, who say parts of the plan will sabotage that much-praised law.

title: Coaxing Troublesome Locks Back Into Service

And so over the years, various mishaps defeat the smooth working of any locks: keys are lost, locks freeze with the bolt in the withdrawn position or fail to respond to manipulation with a key.

Neil L. Rudenstine, the president of Harvard University, is to make the opening and closing remarks. Anne d'Harnoncourt, the president of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, is also to speak.

Striped fabric, hung like little curtains, charmingly replaced Binova's cabinet doors.

title: BARNETT AND BANK SOUTH SIGN ACCORD ON BRANCHES
description: Barnett Banks Inc. and the Bank South Corporation signed a definitive agreement to purchase branches from each other, to strengthen their respective core markets in Florida and Atlanta. The arrangement also gives Barnett a 3.9 percent stake in Bank South. The banking companies expect the transaction to close this fall. Under the arrangement, Barnett will receive all the stock outstanding of Bank South's Pensacola unit, Citizens and Peoples National Bank, a $422 million-asset institution with 11 branches. Barnett will also receive 1.68 million shares of Bank South stock and $55 million in cash. In exchange, Bank South will get 25 offices and $789 million in assets in the Atlanta area from Barnett. Bank South will acquire Barnett Banks of Atlanta, which has 22 offices, and Barnett Banks of Fayette County, which has three offices.

title: NATIONSBANK ASKS FED FOR UNDERWRITING RIGHTS
description: The Nationsbank Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., the fourth-biggest bank in the United States, has asked the Federal Reserve to let it underwrite debt and stock offerings, The Charlotte Observer reported yesterday. Earnings from underwriting could supplement declining profit margins on traditional corporate lending. J. P. Morgan & Company and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation are the only two banks that now have the right to underwrite stock.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A FRIEND once told me that when he was a child, his father would occasionally bring home a live lobster and threaten to make him and his half dozen brothers and sisters eat it. The children would shudder with revulsion at the crawling creature and beg their father to let them have egg salad sandwiches instead for dinner. The parents were thus able to eat their special treat in peace and without breaking the family's food budget. My friend didn't experience the joy of lobster until he was in college and had to pay for it himself.
