The struggling discount retailer, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November, has already closed eight stores since January. The stores are being shuttered to help pay off debt and to focus on the 30 stores that have the best chance to be profitable, the company said. Brendle's also said that it would eliminate 65 jobs at its corporate headquarters in Elkin, N.C. Brendle's employed 3,000 as of February 1992.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MACARONI and cheese is one of those dishes indelibly engraved in my mind as purely American. When I was growing up in France we had various noodle dishes that called for grated Gruyere or aged goat's cheese, but nothing like this bubbling, crusty, creamy concoction that appeals so much to children.

title: Dinkins Passes the Hat Among Supporters at Ellis I.
description: Trying to cash in on a strong showing against his Democratic challengers in several recent polls, Mayor David N. Dinkins was joined by 750 supporters on Ellis Island last night for an elegant salute to his mayoralty and a passing-of-the-hat that his campaign hoped would net $1 million.

title: Review/Dance; City Center and Its Stars Celebrate 50 Years
description: For half a century, City Center has been doing something right. More than that. It has been doing many things right. That was made clear on Monday night in "50 Years at City Center," a gala celebration at this remarkable theater, which has been presenting dance, opera, drama and musical comedy since 1943.

title: East Harlem Schools Have Success Story Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Informers In Bombing Are Missing
description: Two informers who helped the authorities quickly compile early evidence in the World Trade Center bombing investigation have disappeared and appear to have fled, investigators said yesterday.

title: Fugitive General Accuses Peruvian Army, Saying Officers Run Hit Squad
description: When he passed confidential information to a longtime friend and fellow officer, Gen. Rodolfo Robles Espinoza says, he thought he was helping the Peruvian Army investigate the country's most troublesome human rights case -- the summary execution last July of 10 university students and a professor, all suspected of being members of the Shining Path rebel group.

title: Thomas Gambino Is Guilty of Racketeering
description: Thomas Gambino, a Manhattan millionaire who runs a trucking business and whose father gave his name to a Mafia group, was found guilty yesterday of racketeering charges.

title: "ANN TAYLOR STORES CORP. (N)"
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, in reporting smartly higher first-quarter earnings, gave Wall Street the first inkling that prospects were brightening for the specialty store chain that caters to working women.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No one knows which of the two august culinary groups planned their dinner first, but suddenly denizens of the world of food -- restaurant owners, chefs, critics, writers, wine experts -- face a dilemma: two formal sit-down dinners at the same time in different places in Manhattan.

title: Where to Buy a Well-Built Sandwich
description: THE city's sandwich makers are busiest in summer, when New York turns inside out and lunchtime crowds spill into parks, office plazas and nearly every other available open space. Here is a varied menu of sandwiches and where they are made to order at their best. The prices do not include sales tax.

title: Mets Discover a New Loser and a New Way to Lose
description: The Mets are running in place -- literally. Tonight, the Mets lost for the 12th time in 15 games because, among other things, Howard Johnson staggered between second and third base and turned himself into the last out of a triple play. They lost because of Chico Walker's weak defense up the middle and because their new control pitcher, Eric Hillman, could not throw bull's-eyes. They lost because Bobby Bonilla finally blasted a home run -- and there was no other Met on base.

title: In Face of Traffic Accidents, Suffolk Considers Closing Pubs 2 Hours Earlier
description: For 11 years, Suffolk County has led the state in traffic deaths involving drunken driving.

title: From Japan, Big Macs and Marlboros in Stories
description: Haruki Murakami's frequent-flyer fiction crosses the Pacific from Japan effortlessly and makes a soft landing in the United States for the American reader. But I wish the characters in "The Elephant Vanishes," his new book of short stories, wouldn't spend so much time at McDonald's, lighting up Marlboros, listening to Bruce Springsteen records and watching Woody Allen movies as a prelude to romance. Just when you're ready for some wisdom from the Orient, the author serves up a Big Mac.

title: The Economics of Wait and See
description: As economic growth has slowed in the last few months, business executives have exhibited signs of nervousness. Many have scaled back expansion plans, put hiring on the back burner and held down capital spending.

title: McDermott International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 23.9 million for sale of interests in commercial nuclear joint venture, in the quarter and year. The periods also included extraordinary losses of $ 9,821,000 in the quarter and $ 10,431,000 in the year, both from early retirement of debt. The latest year was also after a charge of $ 245,624,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included income of $ 2,802,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and a loss of $ 3,368,000 in the year, both from discontinued operations.d-Net income

title: AT DINNER WITH: Chuck Norris; When That 97-Pound Weakling Grows Up
description: ALL right, if Chuck Norris is such a tough guy, I decided, let's see how he handles Lutece.

title: Venture Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Included a gain of $ 10,323,000, or 61 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.The net income share earnings are based on net applicable to common after dividends on preferred stock. The company paid $ 625,000 in preferred dividends in the latest quarter, and $ 63,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Massachusetts Offers 5 3/4% Yield
description: The largest municipal bond offering yesterday was by Massachusetts, which sold nearly $769 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press on Monday about the increase in the United States prison population misstated the figure in some editions. The total number of inmates in state and Federal prisons was up 59,460 in 1992, a 7.2 percent increase over 1991.

title: A.T.& T. and Kodak in Image-Phone Effort
description: A.T.& T. and the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that they would form an alliance to develop applications for a telephone that displays full-color still images transmitted over ordinary phone lines.

title: Leslie Duly, 57, Dies; Led Bemidji University
description: Dr. Leslie C. Duly, an educator and president of Bemidji State University in Minnesota, died Saturday in his home in Bemidji. He was 57.

title: Clinton Weighs Sending Troops To Macedonia to Limit Conflict
description: President Clinton said today that he is considering sending American troops to Macedonia to aid international peacekeeping forces and to keep the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina from spreading.

title: In Hartford, The Budget Is Passed And Signed
description: The Connecticut General Assembly, after stumbling last week in its effort to pass a budget a month ahead of the deadline, gave final approval today to an $8.58 billion spending plan for the year that begins July 1.

title: Western Beef Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: Year-ago first quarter's sales figure included sales of $ 6,109,314, from the New England wholesale operations sold in September 1992.

title: Presidents Can't Choose Justices in a Vacuum
description: To the Editor:

title: Gold-Stock Sale By Goldsmith
description: Sir James Goldsmith and a group of associates are selling 9.5 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation, the largest American gold company, reports posted at the London exchange on Monday said.

title: Cub Foods Takes Supermarket Honors
description: Cub Foods in Stillwater, Minn., took top honors yesterday at the 27th annual Food Marketing Institute/Woman's Day Advertising Merit Awards competition for supermarket advertising. Cub won three first-place awards and two certificates of merit at a ceremony in Chicago. The Piggly Wiggly Corporation in Memphis followed with two first-place awards and one certificate of merit.

title: CUNY Violated Speech Rights Of Department Chief, Jury Says
description: A Federal jury decided yesterday that the City University of New York had violated Dr. Leonard Jeffries's right to free speech when it removed him as chairman of the City College black studies department last year after he delivered a racially charged speech.

title: Book Notes
description: One Over Par

title: Bulls Take 1-0 Lead As Jordan Scores 43
description: Bulls 91, Cavaliers 84

title: New Allure Publisher Is Named
description: Conde Nast Publications named Alexandra Golinkin as publisher of Allure magazine yesterday.

title: Death cigarettes carry mixed message: Don't smoke, but do buy this product.
description: FOR decades, doctors have been warning that smoking a cigarette is death. Now, Death is a cigarette.

title: Bernice Feinstein, 67, Music History Lecturer
description: Bernice Feinstein, a former lecturer on music history at George Washington University, died on Sunday at King Edward VII Hospital in Bermuda. She was 67 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: A.L. Laboratories Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $ 388,000, or 2 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title: Arrest in Sergeant's Death
description: Amaury Bonilla, 19, of 2314 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested last night and charged with the murder of Staff Sgt. Richard Rodrigues, 32, a marine recruiter who was shot to death Sunday night as he sat on a park bench in East Tremont, the police said. Sergeant Rodrigues died from four shots in the back only a few feet from where his brother, Luis, 27, was fatally wounded 17 months ago.

title: Southwest Air's Gain Noted
description: The Department of Transportation has documented the growing influence of Southwest Airlines, calling the carrier "the dominant airline in the nation's busiest markets."

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of President Clinton's visit to New York City today, the city's Transportation Department is urging motorists not to drive into Manhattan between 2 and 9 P.M.

title: Dinkins Concedes a Setback On Board of Education Post
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins conceded yesterday that he had failed to delay the expected election of Carol A. Gresser today as the new Board of Education president, tacitly acknowledging that he had lost a battle to retain influence over the selection.

title: Peter Zondervan, 84, A Founding Publisher
description: Peter John Zondervan, a founder of one of the nation's largest publishers of religious texts, died on Thursday at the St. Andrews Estates North retirement community in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 84 and lived at St. Andrews.

title: Presidents Can't Choose Justices in a Vacuum; Confidence Is at Stake
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Deadly Sins of Living Linked To Illness as Well as Mortality
description: As if he were a medieval artist depicting the depravity of the seven deadly sins, Dr. Lester Breslow, a California public health specialist, has created a solemn portrait of self-destruction. The weapons are seven unwholesome habits he first identified more than a quarter-century ago.

title: HOW UNITY ELUDED CLINTON ON BOSNIA
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher returned from a week's trip to Europe to inform President Clinton that the only way to break the impasse in the Western alliance over the use of military force in Bosnia was for Mr. Clinton to personally impose a policy on Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: While Europe Stalls . . .
description: With the failure of Secretary of State Christopher's mission to Europe, the Clinton Administration has run out of viable military options for intervening in the Bosnian tragedy. Neither Britain nor France are prepared to support Washington's idea of arming the Bosnian Government and buying time with selective air strikes against Serbian artillery. America is not prepared to intervene in a European quarrel by itself.

title: Oakley Doesn't Mind Being Left in the Open
description: Charles Oakley turned the ignition key of his car, then jumped out to let the car idle. Not that it needed to warm up, as Oakley had uncomfortably discovered.

title: Sports of The Times; Even Schultz Was Caught By 'System'
description: MAKES you wonder. If a thoughtful-sounding leader like Dick Schultz can get tripped up by hints of impropriety at one of America's showcase colleges, what is the point of having tight academic and financial rules for intercollegiate sports?

title: POLAROID SHAREHOLDERS DEFEAT PROPOSAL ON CHIEF'S JOB
description: Shareholders of the Polaroid Corporation defeated a resolution yesterday to split the job of chairman and chief executive, now held by I. MacAllister Booth. The resolution, which was opposed by the Cambridge, Mass., company, was put on the ballot at the company's annual meeting by the New York City Teachers' Retirement System. The pension fund argued that splitting the job would make the chief executive more accountable. The resolution was supported by five New York City pension funds, which together hold about 1 percent of the outstanding shares of Polaroid. A Polaroid spokesman said the proposal was defeated by a "sizable margin." The exact results were not available.

title: A Five-Dollar Cancer Cure
description: It is hard to imagine a world where children are immunized against cancer before their second birthday, where Alzheimer's Disease is cured with a single shot, where AIDS can be taken care of in one visit to the doctor. But before Jonas Salk's discovery in 1952, most Americans couldn't imagine a polio vaccine, either. The fact is, while the health care debate has focused on cutting costs and expanding services, disease and disability continue to drive costs up.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Israeli politics carried an incorrect byline in some editions. The article was by Clyde Haberman.

title: Howe Out at Least 4 Weeks
description: The already sorry state of the Yankees' bullpen became even more grave yesterday when the team announced that Steve Howe would be out four to six weeks with his ankle injury -- a not altogether unexpected development, but certainly not the news the Yankees wanted to hear.

title: 'Show Boat' on Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP., Chicago, plans to close its Richard Brothers Die and Prototype unit this year.

title: Wine Talk
description: BURGUNDY is a seductress. The traveler who keeps his eyes on the road, racing down the auto route from Paris, is probably safe from her blandishments. But beware: a casual glance to the left, toward Aloxe-Corton, semi-submerged in a sea of vines, or to the right, toward the bustling citadel of Beaune, and all may be lost. Burgundy will have claimed another victim. Its art, its history and its people, as much as its vineyards and wine, will have worked their magic.

title: Ericsson (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Loss before taxes.Results are in United States dollars and have been translated at the rate of Swedish kronor 7.785 to the dollar, the exchange rate on March 31, 1993.Net income in the latest first quarter represented earnings referring to income before taxes.Latest quarter included net capital losses of $ 128,000, compared with capital gains of $ 4 million, in year-ago period.Share earnings are after taxes paid and full conversion.

title: IDB Communications Group Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Manuel Alum, 50, A Modern Dancer And Choreographer
description: Manuel Alum, a modern dancer and choreographer, died on Monday at Tisch Hospital in Manhattan. He was 50 and lived in Manhattan.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY JEFFRIES'S RIGHTS VIOLATED, JURY SAYS

title: Voter Bill Passes In a G.O.P. Defeat
description: Senate Democrats broke a Republican filibuster today and sent to President Clinton legislation intended to increase voter registration by almost 50 million people. Mr. Clinton has promised to sign it.

title: Enhance Financial Services Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that its realized gains for the latest first quarter was $ 5.87 million, compared with $ 1.825 million, in year-ago period.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INCREASES PRICES ON ITS DISCOUNT BRAND
description: The Philip Morris Companies raised the wholesale prices yesterday on its deep-discount Basic cigarettes by $2 for every 1,000 cigarettes. The increase means that wholesalers will pay about $41 to $42 for 1,000 cigarettes, Nicholas Rolli, a spokesman for Philip Morris, said. "This change narrows the price differential between our premium and discount cigarettes," he said.

title: Stein Proposes Requiring Bids For the Underwriting of Bonds
description: Responding to recent news reports about the selection of bond underwriters in New York City and New Jersey, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, proposed yesterday that the city request companies to submit sealed, competitive bids for its $5 billion-a-year bond underwriting business.

title: Airwaves Auction Bill Advances
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would for the first time allow the Government to auction radio frequencies. The frequencies will be used for advanced wireless telephones and other new technologies.

title: Mercantile Stores Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Included a gain of $ 3.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change for income taxes.c-Net loss, which included after-tax charge of $ 10.5 million from relocation provision, a charge of $ 12.2 million from the cumulative effect of accounting for post-retirement benefits, and an extraordinary loss of $ 5,550,000 from debt retirement costs.

title: Review/Film: Time Indefinite; Taking the Measure of One's Life Through the Lens of Death
description: Intriguing contradictions run to the heart of Ross McElwee's enthralling autobiographical film journal, "Time Indefinite." Even though the creator and central figure in this cinema verite documentary matter-of-factly bares his anxieties about death, marriage and parenthood, he emerges as a shadowy enigma, a man in hiding. And since "Time Indefinite" comes about as close as a movie can to capturing the texture of everyday life, what does this absence of personality imply about film reality versus actual experience?

title: Andreychuk Goals Lift Leafs to 3-2 Lead
description: Maple Leafs 5, Blues 1

title: Dr. David Blankenhorn, 68, Dies; Pioneer in Heart Disease Research
description: Dr. David H. Blankenhorn, a professor of medicine at the University of Southern California who pioneered research showing that a low-fat diet and drug therapy could reverse heart disease, died Sunday at his home in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 68.

title: N.C.A.A.'s Executive Director Decides to Resign
description: Dick Schultz, who has led an effort to reform the National Collegiate Athletic Association since he took over as its executive director in 1987, resigned yesterday after deciding the organization could be damaged by a controversy involving his own integrity.

title: The Quest and the Questions
description: What's the running joke in Atlanta, which fought diligently to be the host for Super Bowl XXVIII on Jan. 30, 1994? The word is that if the Buffalo Bills are in the game, Atlanta wants to toss it right back to the National Football League.

title: Cardinal Distribution Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a termination fee of $ 13,466,000 and non-recurring charges of $ 9,882,000.

title: Facing 4th Year of Cuts, Berkeley Chancellor Leads Budget Revolt
description: Over three years of state budget cuts, the University of California has reacted more or less stoically, with administrators saying they would simply have to run a leaner, more competitive institution.

title: Topics of The Times; A Mosaic Moment
description: A woman approached a Manhattan sidewalk display of bags and wallets, examined the merchandise and then asked the price of a particular pocketbook (genuine leather). "Veinticinco," said the proprietor of about 15 square feet of sidewalk on Seventh Avenue at 28th Street.

title: High Levels of Lead Found In Water Serving 30 Million
description: In its broadest survey of lead contamination in drinking water, the Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that 819 systems serving 30 million people had excessive levels, and it ordered officials to take steps to reduce lead levels and to notify customers.

title: Study Points the Way To Lower Cholesterol
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: New Zagat Guide

title: Witt's Big Outing Is Supported by (Gasp!) the Bullpen
description: Mike Witt pitched seven marvelous innings before Buck Showalter asked him to sit. Witt didn't want to. He had a three-hitter, a hefty lead and a successful curveball, and he was enjoying his start against the Milwaukee Brewers last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Raid of Drug Lab Led to Arrests In Assassination of a Journalist
description: No one knew it at the time, but when Federal agents raided a warehouse in a gritty industrial neighborhood in Brooklyn last June and found a laboratory that refined 100 to 200 pounds of cocaine a day, they had serendipitously uncovered the first break in the long, frustrating investigation into the killing of Manuel de Dios Unanue.

title: Seaboard Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-After a gain of $ 20,074,000, or $ 13.49 a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Moody's Gives Junk Rating To $4.6 Billion of Delta Debt
description: The rating on about $4.6 billion of long-term debt of Delta Air Lines was lowered to junk bond status yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which is concerned about the operating performance and cash flow of the No. 3 domestic airline.

title: Rabin Staves Off Collapse of Israeli Coalition, at Least for a Week
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today averted an immediate Government crisis that had threatened his parliamentary majority, but he may have only delayed the day of reckoning by a week.

title: Turgeon in Game 6? Chance Near 0
description: Now that Mario Lemieux has overcome back problems -- temporarily, at least -- to lead his Pittsburgh Penguins to a victory, is it possible that Pierre Turgeon will surmount a shoulder injury and do a similar thing for the Islanders?

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Nordstrom Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
GLEASON SHARES RISE ON NEWS OF A STAKE BY BASS GROUP
description: The shares of the Gleason Corporation of Rochester rose $1.25 yesterday, or 9.8 percent, to $14, on the New York Stock Exchange on the news that a group including members of the Bass family of Texas had bought a 5.5 percent stake in the company. The news was disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Gleason produces gears used in vehicle, aircraft and equipment drivetrains.

title: PNC Bank Buying Sears Loan Unit
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would sell its large mortgage banking company for $329 million in cash to the PNC Bank Corporation, which is as eager to diversify as Sears is to return to its core retail business.

title: Continental Jet Deal Seen With Boeing
description: Continental Airlines is expected to announce today that it has ordered more than 75 Boeing 737 and 757 jets worth several billion dollars, people familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: In the Cellar
description: Megacards Inc. makes and markets baseball cards and other sports picture cards. At this time last year, as the 1992 baseball season was beginning, its share price was around $8. But the St. Louis company's stock has been falling ever since. Yesterday, it was one of the biggest percentage losers in Nasdaq trading.

title: Topics of The Times; Freya Stark's Journey
description: "If we could make contours in hearts as we do in maps, to see their loves, we should learn what strange unexpected regions attain the deepest depth. Often we might discover that a place rather than a person holds the secret."

title: Lester del Rey, 77, Editor and Author
description: Lester del Rey, an editor and author of dozens of science-fiction novels, died on Monday at New York Hospital. A resident of Manhattan, he was 77.

title: Gephardt Lends Support To the Free-Trade Pact
description: The House majority leader today broadly endorsed the Clinton Administration's trade policies toward Mexico and Japan, while calling for legislation later this year to extend the use of trade sanctions in labor and environmental disputes.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: RISOTTO is a perfect example to show that the microwave oven provides benefits that have little to do with its acclaimed rapidity. In fact, cooking risotto in the microwave is only marginally quicker than cooking it on top of the stove. The advantages are a consistent and superior finished dish made in a cool kitchen without the constant stirring and vigilance of the cooking. This factor frees the cook to do other things, like making a main course if the risotto is to be a first course, or washing salad greens, or setting the table.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS This Time, McEnroe Defeats Connors Patrick McEnroe was a 7-5, 7-5 winner over Jimmy Connors last night in the first round of the America's Red Clay Championship in Coral Springs, Fla. This was the first time the two played since their stirring opening-round match at the 1991 United States Open. At that time, Connors rebounded from a two-set, 0-3 deficit to win in five sets and make a theatrical march to the semifinals. But the 40-year-old Connors is now concentrating on business ventures and the start of his 35-and-older tour. He has played in only five tournaments this year, losing in the first round four times, and is ranked 172d in the world. Last night, he was betrayed by an erratic serve. In the 11th game of the first set, he served three of his six double faults, virtually handing the set to the McEnroe, who is ranked 88th. (AP) Lendl Is Upset at Italian Open: Fifth-seeded Ivan Lendl was eliminated in the opening round of the Italian Open in Rome, losing to Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-2, 6-1. Second-seeded Jim Courier, the defending champion, rolled past Horacio de la Pena, 6-2, 6-1, and No. 3 Boris Becker beat Andrei Cherkasov, 6-4, 6-3. Sixth-seeded Michael Chang defeated Jordi Arrese, 6-2, 6-3. (AP)

title: U.N. of Pit Crews Revs For Old Brooklyn Poly
description: REMEMBER the 1969 Mets, Harry S. Truman in 1948, David? Well, slingshot, longshot and underdog fans, meet the car racing team from Brooklyn Polytechnic University.

title: Christopher Sergel, Publisher of Plays And Playwright, 75
description: Christopher R. Sergel, the president of the Dramatic Publishing Company and a Broadway playwright, died on Friday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 75.

title: Eating Well
description: FOR the first time, the Government is asking the public whether it wants food labels to include information about substances that are used in food production. And the Government will make the decision using an outside advisory panel that includes consumer representatives.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ailing Johnson Is Probable
description: Larry Johnson cut short his workout with the Hornets yesterday in Charlotte after 10 minutes, saying his bruised right foot was stiff and causing him pain.

title: Pentagon Warns McDonnell It May Cancel C-17 Program
description: The Pentagon warned the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday that it would end the development of the C-17 cargo plane unless the contractor overhauled the troubled program, which has been hit by delays, cost overruns and technical problems.

title: Public & Private; Where's the Pork?
description: To Bill Clinton

title: TOUGH QUESTIONING OF LIBEL PLAINTIFF
description: Jeffrey M. Masson's memory was challenged on the witness stand today when cross-examination highlighted quotations he had once disputed in Janet Malcolm's articles in The New Yorker magazine, only to hear them later, in his own voice, on tape-recordings of their interviews.

title: Look Inward, Tokyo Urges Trade Critics
description: Under intense pressure from trading partners to open its markets, Japan counterattacked today, accusing the United States and other nations of engaging in unfair trade practices.

title: Elbit Ltd. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 9,385,000 from the change in holdings of its Elscint Ltd. unit, and charges of $ 2,017,000 from the company's reorganization of its U.S. operations following the acquisition of the Electronic Manufacturing Center from General Dynamics Corp., and the adoption of FASB No. 109. The period also included a charge of $ 835,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bishops Plot Stance if Health Plan Covers Abortion
description: The nation's Roman Catholic archbishops held a private meeting in Chicago yesterday to discuss what stance they will take toward a national health-care plan if it covers abortions.

title: Compromise on Military Gay Ban Gaining Support Among Senators
description: Senior Senate Democrats and Republicans are beginning to coalesce around a proposal that would end the military's efforts at unmasking homosexuals but would continue to bar gay men and women from serving if they are open about their sexuality.

title: Factory Raid Nets 45 Arrests and a Million T-Shirts
description: As part of a drive against illegal street vending, the Dinkins administration announced yesterday that the police had arrested 45 people and seized more than a million imitation designer T-shirts from manufacturing operations housed in a Manhattan building.

title: Subway Caper Fueled by Passion for Trains
description: Sixteen-year-old Keron Thomas's obsession with subway trains did not begin in early childhood because in early childhood he was in Trinidad and Trinidad does not have trains.

title: Record Store of Near Future: Computers Replace the Racks
description: Computer technology has turned its hungry gaze on a pair of well-known institutions: the record store and the video shop.

title: SERBIA'S PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MEETING OF HIS COUNTRYMEN
description: In a move apparently intended to override the rejection of an international peace plan by Bosnian Serb leaders, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia demanded on Tuesday that the leaders cancel their proposed referendum on the plan.

title: Bronx Girl, 7, Shot in Dispute Over a Bottle
description: A 7-year-old Bronx girl was critically injured last night when she got in the way of two men arguing about cleaning up a broken beer bottle. One of the men, an assistant building superintendent, shot at the other, a tenant, grazing his elbow but striking the child in the abdomen.

title: 10 Students Given Churchill Grants
description: Ten American college students have been awarded this year's Winston Churchill Scholarships for graduate work in mathematics, engineering and the sciences at Cambridge University.

title: Bus Accord Lifts Hopes For Unions
description: In the Greyhound terminal here, two groups of bus drivers crossed paths. They stopped to look at one other, as if something ought to be said. But there were no words exchanged, just glares.

title: Dollar General Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago first quarter's results were restated to reflect February 1993 5-for-4 stock split. Previously, Dollar General reported net income of 14 cents a share, based on average shares of 27,165,000 for the first quarter of 1992.

title: Out of Prison and Now Armed With a Rare Second Chance
description: There is always, in conversation with Bernard Hopkins, his recollections of fighting on the streets of Philadelphia, of how "I used my boxing skills to beat up people as an enforcer." And there is also his willingness to talk of more than four years in prison for a chain-snatching.

title: Limited's Net Off Despite Sales Gain
description: Although first-quarter sales at The Limited Inc. grew at a relatively healthy clip, a malaise at three of its largest divisions caused profits to dip slightly.

title: How an Actor Found Comedy and Tragedy In Battling Leukemia
description: If you are Evan Handler, you are pretty much resigned to the reality that most theatergoers don't remember your critically praised roles on Broadway. What people are more likely to recall is the incident that sparked news items and a collectible New York Post headline: "Broadway Swordplay Becomes Real: Hamlet Actor Storms Off Stage After Co-Star Whacks Him."

title: Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 576,000, or 4 cents a share, reflecting a change in accounting for income tax.

title: The Unfinished Abortion Battle
description: President Clinton is pro-choice. So, according to a recent ABC News/Washington Post Poll, are most Americans. So, it appears, is Congress.

title: Bridge
description: The first cash-prize tournament under the auspices of the American Contract Bridge League was played in Las Vegas, Nev., last weekend. The biggest winners, sharing $5,000 for winning the Open Pairs, were Sabine Zenkel of Chicago and Daniela von Arnim of Wiesbaden, who often represent Germany internationally.

title: Official Quits At Shearson
description: Prudential Securities said yesterday that it had hired Alan A. Rhein, an executive vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers, to manage all of Prudential's 300 branch offices and 6,000 brokers.

title: LESLIE FAY GETS APPROVAL TO USE $150 MILLION CREDIT LINE
description: The Leslie Fay Companies said yesterday that the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan had allowed the company to use its entire $150 million credit facility. The apparel maker, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on April 5 in the wake of an accounting scandal, said that the one-year revolving credit line would permit it to issue letters of credit to its international suppliers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday, about the appointment of Arthur Andersen & Company as the auditor of the Leslie Fay Companies, misattributed the disclosure of accounting irregularities at the company. They were first disclosed by Leslie Fay's controller, not its previous auditor. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of John S. Dubel, Leslie Fay's chief financial officer. A former Arthur Andersen partner, Mr. Dubel is not a member of Leslie Fay's audit committee.

title: No Headline
description: "It's not like getting behind the wheel of a Chevy and pulling away from the curb. He came almost fully equipped. And you know the old saying: If it walks like a duck and talks like a duck, it's a motorman." -- ALBERT W. O'LEARY, New York City Transit Police spokesman. [ B2:1. ]

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE
description: Syracuse

title: Oracle Links With U S West
description: The Oracle Corporation, a Silicon Valley software publisher, and U S West, the regional telephone company based in Englewood, Colo., announced a partnership today to develop technology that could provide a range of multimedia services for the home, from home shopping to video conferencing.

title: Bonuses Planned For U.S. Medalists
description: The United States Olympic Committee is planning to offer bonuses of $15,000, and possibly more, to most American athletes who win gold medals at the next winter and summer Olympic Games.

title: Out of Laos, a Distinctive Variation of Familiar Asian Cuisine
description: SINCE the Vietnam War ended, more than 60,000 Laotians fleeing their country's Communist regime have settled in the fertile San Joaquin Valley of central California, drawn by the hope of farm jobs.

title: Russia Dusts Off a Long-Unused Security Council Tactic: The Veto
description: Russia used its Security Council veto for the first time in nine years today to kill a plan to change the financing of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TIPPER GORE carried her camera on the campaign trail when her husband was running for the Vice Presidency, and tomorrow, 40 of her photographs go on view at the Woodrow Wilson House in Washington, in an exhibit that will continue through June 28.

title: Build a Better Sandwich and . . . Yes! It's In!
description: IN the course of human events, sandwiches have been maligned and exalted, have been delicate contrivances and overstuffed plebian affairs, alternately objects of desire and objects of scorn.

title: First Brands Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary charge of $ 7,128,000 for the repurchase of subordinated debt.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 10,760,000 for the repurchase of subordinated debt, and included one-time restructuring expense of $ 3.5 million.Year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect change in accounting principles for inventories (LIFO to FIFO) and for income taxes.

title: A Return to Profits for Equitable
description: The Equitable reported yesterday its first profitable quarter since 1989 -- the latest chapter in the turnaround story of an insurance giant that faced insolvency as recently as two years ago.

title: United Retail Group Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Net loss, which included extraordinary charges--$ 16,330,000 of general, administrative and store operating expenses and $ 6,083 of interest expense.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a panel set up to increase productivity of the New York City work force referred incorrectly to the research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, as did an article on May 4 about criticism of Mayor David N. Dinkins's spending plan for the next fiscal year. The research director is Charles Brecher.

title: Critics Circle Names 'Angels' Best Play
description: Tony Kushner's "Angels in America: Millennium Approaches" was named best new play of the season by the New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday. The Critics Circle also selected Frank McGuinness' "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me" as the best new foreign play and "Kiss of the Spider Woman" as the best new musical.

title: L.L. Bean Switches Boston Agencies
description: L. L. Bean in Freeport, Me., has selected Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston to handle its account, which had been at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston for six years. Billings were estimated to exceed $5 million.

title: Marvin M. Schwan, 64, Builder Of a Billion-Dollar Food Empire
description: Marvin M. Schwan, who transformed his father's local door-to-door dairy company into a billion-dollar food empire covering 49 states, died on Sunday at a hospital in San Diego. He was 64 and lived in Sioux Falls, S.D.

title: Recession? Why Worry?
description: Reputable economic attitudes hold that the economic norm is high, if not quite full, employment and a reliable rate of expansion in economic output. Recessions are an aberrant departure from that norm. Correction must come. The question after nearly three years is whether this is so. Or is it possible that the economy has settled into an underemployment equilibrium of small or negligible growth?

title: INSIDE
description: Dinkins Unlikely to Delay Vote

title: Good Demand at Treasury Auction
description: The Treasury's quarterly auction got off to a respectable start yesterday with the sale of $16 billion in three-year notes.

title: Pennsylvania Station Rebirth Will Aid Region
description: To the Editor:

title: Tarkanian's Reaction: Sorry to See Schultz Go
description: Throughout the bitter legal battles he has waged against the National Collegiate Athletic Association, Jerry Tarkanian and his lawyers have sent many emotional letters to the organization's office outside Kansas City. But not one quite like the one he sent Monday.

title: Books of The Times; From Japan, Big Macs and Marlboros in Stories
description: The Elephant Vanishes By Haruki Murakami Translated by Alfred Birnbaum and Jay Rubin. 327 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Finding of Murder In Indians' Deaths
description: An Indian couple found dead in their Park Avenue apartment last month were asphyxiated, apparently by robbers, the New York City Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Curbing Drivers Who Kill
description: Eight-year-old Jonathan Medina, killed by a hit-and-run driver whose license had been suspended 41 times . . . 2-year-old Federico Santos, killed by a driver with two dozen violations and no valid driver's license . . . 4-year-old Dejon Barra, killed by a driver with 63 suspensions . . . nearly a dozen pedestrians also injured in these incidents.

title: Health Plan Expected to Cover Prescription Drugs
description: A senior White House official said today that President Clinton's health plan would probably guarantee insurance coverage for prescription drugs and for some long-term care, so elderly people need not impoverish themselves to qualify for assistance in paying for a nursing home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about a Supreme Court decision upholding an Ohio reapportionment plan misstated the number of legislative districts with black majorities created under the plan. It was five, not eight. That error was repeated in a Law page article on April 16 about a lawsuit challenging North Carolina's Congressional reapportionment.

title: Burrell Wins Prudential Business
description: Two agencies that specialize in advertising and marketing programs aimed at minority consumers received new assignments yesterday.

title: Sharply and Loudly, G.O.P. Rivals Debate
description: The three major candidates for the New Jersey Republican gubernatorial nomination participated in their first televised debate tonight, getting little chance to differentiate themselves from their rivals but giving voters across the state a barb-filled, free-wheeling 90-minute preview of the final weeks of the campaign.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 BOSNIAN SERBS REBUFF BELGRADE Leading Serbian politicians demanded that Bosnian Serbs forsake a peace plan referendum and instead join representatives of ethnic Serbs of all former Yugoslav territories in a vote, but Bosnian Serbs rebuffed the proposal, which would almost certainly endorse the plan. A1 CHRISTOPHER'S COURSE The Secretary of State's mission to Europe to discuss the war in Bosnia may have been doomed by strong opposition and a lack of room to maneuver. A1

title: Black Beans via China
description: BLACK beans are a popular ingredient of Cantonese cooking. They make a happy marriage with scallops, as they do with just about any kind of seafood you can think of, from shrimp to flounder. They also match well with chicken and frogs' legs.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM UNIT COMPLETES $100 MILLION SALE
description: BP Chemicals Inc. of Cleveland has completed the $100 million sale of its nitrogen chemicals unit to Arcadian Partners L.P., a fertilizer distributor based in Memphis. BP Chemicals, a subsidiary of British Petroleum P.L.C., will continue to operate the Lima, Ohio, facilities for Arcadian under a three-year agreement. The facility includes ammonia, urea, nitric acid and solution blending operations. The acquisition is expected to increase Arcadian's ammonia production by 30 percent.

title: Review/Cabaret; An All-American Voice
description: Steeped in the traditions of the European boite and the Manhattan after-hours club, cabaret is not a genre that is readily associated with the musical climate of sunny California. But as Amanda McBroom, a singer, songwriter and actress from Los Angeles, demonstrates in her wonderful new act at the Russian Tea Room, there is definitely a place for an extroverted all-American voice in a genre that is too often associated with an attitude of world-weary sophistication.

title: Spring Heat Can't Melt Islanders' New Ice Age
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins may still win their third consecutive Stanley Cup championship this spring. They are the best team in the National Hockey League. They have the best player, Mario Lemieux, who is healthy again after suffering with back problems. And the Penguins are playing an underdog Islander team that is without its best player, Pierre Turgeon.

title:
Market Place;
German interest rates may be falling but stocks aren't rising.
description: THE Frankfurt Stock Exchange performed surprisingly well in the first quarter, helped by expectations of lower German interest rates and hopes that economic recovery in the United States would be strong enough to help pull Germany's export-oriented economy out of its recession.

title: John Hersey Memorial
description: A memorial service for the writer John Hersey is to be held on Saturday at 2 P.M. at Battell Chapel of Yale University, Elm and College Streets in New Haven. Mr. Hersey, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1944 for his novel "A Bell for Adano," died on March 24 at his home in Key West, Fla., at 78. Howard R. Lamar, Yale's president, and others are to speak. Mr. Hersey graduated from Yale in 1936.

title: Producer Price Rise Jars Treasury Market
description: There was a rude awakening for the Treasury market yesterday: The April jump in producer price inflation was much higher than expected and signaled that there is less hope now for a new rally based on declining inflation.

title: Review/Television; Bart and All, Outrageously
description: If you just want to count guest stars, evidently the hottest television show of the moment is a cartoon. Of course, "The Simpsons" isn't just any cartoon. It also happens to be one of the most inventive and cheekiest romps on prime time. Lending one's voice to the animation has become a prestige stint, and tonight's season finale, on Fox at 8, sets a record with a lineup that includes Johnny Carson, Hugh Hefner, Bette Midler, Luke Perry, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Elizabeth Taylor.

title: ITALIAN EXECUTIVE FACES GRAFT CASE
description: The head of the biggest Italian public corporation, with interests from banks and supermarkets to the national airline Alitalia, was arrested on corruption charges today as the 15-month-old bribery investigation pressed deeper into the vast state industries.

title: Internet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 1,188,000, or 14 cents a share, from the retirement of debt.c-Net loss

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: U.S. Weather Service Shuts a Local Window
description: NEXT year, for the first time in almost a century, Connecticut will be without a weather forecast center of its own.

title: New York Refinancing Correctional Bonds
description: Strong investor demand and low interest rates continue to encourage bond refundings, in which proceeds are used to pay off bonds sold when rates were higher.

title: Review/Dance; The Wider Dimension of Lubovitch's Male Duet
description: Two men in white approach each other from opposite sides of the stage, dance together with the clarity of geometric form and then part, exiting separately into the wings from which they entered. The dancers' mutual support speaks of a caring relationship.

title: 'Hi-yo, Kemo Sabe!' A King of Nostalgia
description: IT is 12:03 P.M., Saturday, on the 17th floor of the CBS building on West 52d Street, and the Ingram mess, as Dan Ingram himself calls it, has begun to spread out for 60 miles on the FM band.

title: Dinkins Plan For Homeless Under Attack
description: The Dinkins administration's proposal to create a new agency for homeless services -- a centerpiece in the administration's plans to overhaul the city's troubled shelter system -- has run into widespread opposition in the City Council.

title: 'I Love Tourism': 3 States Try To Resume Luring Visitors
description: Fifteen years after New York tourism officials imprinted the phrase "I Love New York" on the nation's collective consciousness and "New Jersey and You" seemed so perfect together, efforts to promote the metropolitan region as a travel destination are emerging from their darkest hour.

title: For Clinton, Barricades But Few Hands to Shake
description: Maybe it was the police presence that made Cooper Square look like an occupied country. Maybe it was the prospect of waiting in the hot sun for three hours. Or maybe, it was simply that spectacle-weary New Yorkers would just as soon have watched the whole thing on television.

title: Flights of Fancy For the Garden
description: ARCHITECTS cannot resist designing quirky weather vanes and birdhouses, though they may lack clients who want them. So when charities beckon, architects get to work indulging their fantasies.

title: Shellshocked Island Has Had Enough of the Navy
description: When the Pentagon recently announced its list of 165 military bases to be completely or partly closed, people here were angry and disappointed. Despite their best efforts, the Navy "weapons training facility" that occupies two-thirds of this small island just east of Puerto Rico was not placed on the list.

title: 18 Suburban Homes: A Dream Undermined
description: The American dream holds nine families hostage here.

title: Cascades Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,823,000, or 3 cents a share, from the dilution of its stake in an affiliate.Preferred-share dividends were $ 1,648,000 in the latest quarter.The company said that the sales increase is due to the inclusion in the latest period of the sales of Paperboard Industries Corp. and Rolland Inc.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Regency Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses on the extinguishment of debt of $ 48,000 in the quarter and $ 137,000 in the 9 months. The 9 months also included extraordinary gain of $ 99,000, or 1 cent a share, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.c-Included extraordinary gains of $ 221,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 629,000, or 18 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Recoton Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect 33-1/3 percent stock dividend distributed on Dec. 11, 1992.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: ICH Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses for costs associated with early debt retirement of $ 1,231,000, and included non-operating after-tax gain of $ 79.5 million, or $ 1.66 a share, from initial public offering of common stock by Bankers Life Holding Corp.c-Net loss, which included charge for changes in accounting principles for postretirement benefits of $ 1,812,000, and extraodinary loss for costs associated with early debt retirement of $ 2,516,000.ICH said that results for the quarter ended March 31 also included a $ 5.4 million investment gain from Bankers Life Holding's redemption of securities held by ICH.The company also said its first quarter operating earnings also contain a $ 17.1-million gain on a terminated reinsurance agreement between Bankers Life and an ICH subsidiary. ICH owns 24.4 percent of Bankers Life's common shares. ICH said that the year-ago quarter included a $ 17.8-million charge for the settlement of litigation.

title: Foe of Chancellor Elected Head Of New York City School Board
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday elected as its new president the board member who cast the deciding vote to oust Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, a move that underscores just how much Mayor David N. Dinkins has lost control of the board.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Lauren Wagner Soprano Weill Recital Hall

title: Review/Theater; Dreams and Clowns: Bergman's Vision In a New 'Peer Gynt'
description: In his vision of "Peer Gynt" (at the Brooklyn Academy of Music), Ingmar Bergman interprets the Ibsen epic as both dream play and clown play. Searching for a key to unlock this awesome poetic drama, the director finds it in Peer's childhood fantasies, the dreams that he shares with his mother. To a background of trolls and international intrigue, the title character acts out one man's lifelong quest for spiritual self-awareness.

title: Sin or Not, Supposed Relic Of Cross Is Sold in France
description: Despite warnings by a Vatican official that it is a sin to trade in relics, two slivers of olive wood said to come from the cross on which Jesus was crucified were sold for more than $18,000 in a crowded auction house here today.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK COMPLETES RIGHTS OFFERING
description: Dime Savings Bank of New York said yesterday that it had completed a $193 million rights offering and expects to meet its June 30 capital targets. The company said it had issued about 33.1 million new shares for $6 each, to meet capital ratios set by the Office of Thrift Supervision last year. Under the terms of the offering, shareholders received 1.1 rights for each share of stock owned on the April 15 record date. The bank expects to complete the issuance of all shares by May 20.

title: Charles and Diana Taped? M.I.5 Snooping Denied
description: The British Government said today that it was possible that private conversations among members of the royal family had been surreptitiously recorded, but it denied responsibility for what a newspaper asserted was a tape of an argument last year between the Prince and Princess of Wales.

title: Pennsylvania Abortion Law To Be Argued in Court Again
description: A Federal district judge in Reading today gave Planned Parenthood a new opportunity to challenge a state law restricting abortions.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: FRUIT OF THE LOOM INC., Chicago, will spend $50 million to build a 500,000-square-foot production facility in Vidalia, La. The plant is expected to be ready in 1995 and will employ 1,000 workers.

title: Elron Electronic Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 328,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change.Elron Electronic said that during the first quarter, its share from its 39.3 percent owned affliate, Elbit Ltd., was $ 4.8 million. Also during the quarter, some investors exercised their options to buy from Elron 100,000 ordinary shares of Elbit, and the balance of convertible debentures and some options issued by Elbit in a public offering in 1990 were exercised. These actions netted Elron $ 1.2 million, and decreased its holdings in Elbit from 41.6 percent to 39.3 percent.

title: A New Shine
description: The Armor All Products Corporation makes car polishes and protective finishes. But since it hit a peak of more than $20 in December, the stock has drifted downward. Yesterday, a major shareholder, the McKesson Corporation, sold a large block, increasing the liquidity of Armor All stock and prompting investors to bid up the shares.

title: Arbour May Prove No Man Is an Islander Forever
description: By taking the Islanders to the late stages of the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, Coach Al Arbour has enhanced his reputation and, at the same time, his bargaining power. Arbour won't talk about it, but he will be, in essence, a free agent this summer at a time when several coaching jobs are likely to be open.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sampras and Courier Work for Victories Pete Sampras and Jim Courier, ranked No. 1 and No. 2 in the world, overcame tough matches yesterday to reach the round of 16 in the Italian Open in Rome. Sampras defeated qualifier Alex Corretja, 6-4, 7-5. Sampras staved off a set point, coming back from 4-5, 15-40 in the second set. Courier, the defending champion, needed three sets to defeat 83d-ranked Paul Haarhuis, 6-3, 2-6, 6-0. Boris Becker, seeded third, overpowered qualifier Sandor Noszaly, 6-3, 6-2, and No. 4 Goran Ivanisevic defeated Magnus Gustafsson, 6-3, 6-4. Sixth-seeded Michael Chang rallied to defeat qualifer Andrea Gaudenzi, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3. Last year's runner-up, 15th-seeded Carlos Costa, was upset by Christian Bergstrom, 6-2, 6-7 (7-3), 6-3. (AP) Graf Rallies: Defending champion Steffi Graf, seeded No. 1, recovered from a disastrous first set to beat fellow German Sabine Hack, 0-6, 6-3, 6-2, and advance at the German Open in Berlin. Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini overpowered Marketa Kochta, 6-1, 6-0, and No. 3 Mary Joe Fernandez defeated Isabelle Demongeot, 6-0, 6-3. Fourth-seeded Jennifer Capriati overcame Wiltrud Probst, 6-2, 4-6, 6-0. (AP) SOCCER Cup Winners Cup Goes to Parma Lorenzo Minotti and Alessandro Melli scored first-half goals last night, leading Parma of Italy to a 3-1 victory over Royal Antwerp of Belgium in the final of the European Cup Winners Cup in Wembley, England. It was the first European trophy for Parma, fourth in the Italian League this season with a 14-9-7 record. (AP)

title: Free-Agent Center Chooses the Patriots
description: The New England Patriots, continuing their search for a center, have signed the unrestricted free agent BILL LEWIS to a two-year contract. Lewis also considered offers from Minnesota and Seattle. Details of the deal were not released.

title: Tradeoffs and Benefits of a California H.M.O.
description: The health-care delivery system that is being hailed as the wave of the future is the only system Dr. Rhoda Nussbaum has ever known. Since graduating from medical school in 1982, she has been a salaried obstetrician-gynecologist in San Francisco, on the staff of a health maintenance organization.

title: H & H Oil Tool Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Classical Music in Review
description: James Richman Harpsichordist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Cost-Free Aid for New York City
description: Mayor David Dinkins's new budget for New York City counts on more state aid than the $6 billion already committed. Forget it, some seasoned observers say. The Legislature has sealed the state's budget for fiscal 1994, and isn't about to reopen it for Mr. Dinkins. But that misses the point.

title: Facts, Not Species, Are Periled
description: If President Clinton signs the Rio accord to protect rare and endangered species, he will place scientific truth in greater danger than endangered species.

title: U.N. Steps Said to Dry Up Serbs' Cash
description: A looming cash shortage brought on by the latest United Nations sanctions is a major element in the sudden push by Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, for peace in Bosnia, Administration officials say.

title: Turner Broadcasting System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an accounting charge of $ 306 million reflecting the adoption of FAS No. 109.c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 1,375,000 from tax loss carryforward.

title: Events: Tours and Fairs, Quilts and Azaleas
description: Wright Community Municipal Art Society, the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 397-3809.

title: Home Video
description: Action movies deliver thrills on screen, and as Hollywood has discovered, they also make for a star-studded breed of interactive video game. Thanks to the multi-media compact disk, called CD-ROM, the Arnold Schwarzeneggers and Sylvester Stallones can jump into the contest, too.

title: You Read The Book, Now Quiz The Author
description: Years before she became a best-selling author, Sue Miller enjoyed the intellectual challenge and camaraderie of a reading group. She and some academic colleagues from the Boston area met every few weeks for nearly eight years to discuss Kundera, Foucault and Coetzee.

title: Profits in Quarter Doubled At the News Corporation
description: The News Corporation, the Australian media conglomerate headed by Rupert Murdoch, reported yesterday that after-tax operating profit, after unusual items, more than doubled in its fiscal third quarter, to $129.6 million from $59.4 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Olympia's Creditors in U.S. Square Off With Canadians
description: Creditors of the main United States branch of the Canadian real estate giant Olympia & York Developments Ltd. are becoming increasingly irritated over efforts by Canadian interests to broaden their influence and might take legal steps including forcing the American unit into bankruptcy, people close to the parties say.

title: 10 Rivals Will Try to Keep Sea Hero From Gaining a Second Jewel
description: Who -- or what -- can beat Sea Hero when he tries to win the 118th Preakness this Saturday?

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Tom Jones Limelight

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Bank of Delaware, Wilmington, a unit of PNC Bank Corp., Pittsburgh, $200 million of 3.30 percent notes due in 1994 at par through Merrill Lynch & Co. The noncallable issue is rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Woolworth Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IF you have difficulty starting up your gasoline-powered mowers, garden tillers, string-trimmers or other yard-care machines in the spring, you may have neglected them when you stored them in the fall. When the equipment hasn't been properly maintained -- the gas and oil emptied, the filters cleaned -- problems like difficulty in starting and poor performance result. Following are some simple procedures for curing common engine woes.

title: Citing Safety, Airline Curbs CD and Computer Use
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would join the growing number of carriers that have banned the use of laptop computers, compact-disk players and other electronic devices during takeoffs and landings. The policy underlines an emerging safety issue in which questions outnumber answers.

title: Astro Sciences Corp. reports earnings for Year to March 31
Corrections
description: A table yesterday showing localities with high levels of lead in water carried an incomplete description of the statistics. The table listed water systems serving more than 50,000 customers apiece and identified as exceeding the Federal lead standard. The number shown for each system was the minimum measurement in the 10 percent of houses with the worst lead levels. The measurements were expressed in parts per billion.

title: Yankees Have That Rundown Feeling
description: In reality, the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Yankees with an unaccustomed burst of power in the first two innings and an excellent performance by Bill Wegman on the mound. That is not, however, how the Yankees will remember it.

title: NYMagic Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 1,221,297, or 11 cents a share, resulting from the cumulative effect of a change in the method of accounting for income taxes.NYMagic said that there were realized investment gains of $ 2,949,263 in the latest first quarter, and $ 939,744 in the year-ago period.

title: Round One in G.O.P. TV Debates May Have Gone to Florio
description: The first televised debate of the election season may have been among three Republicans, but Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, may have come out as much a winner as any of them.

title: Bosnia and the Credibility Trap
description: The debate over U.S. military intervention in Bosnia is reaching a fever pitch. Senators Bob Dole and Joseph Biden are talking tough from both sides of the aisle. Newsweek warned in its latest issue that President Clinton "can't back down without looking weak." A Time magazine cover story stated that the President will "risk a loss of credibility by backing away." And on Sunday's "McLaughlin Group," the pundit Fred Barnes promised that without intervention -- unilateral if necessary -- Mr. Clinton will henceforth be considered "President Marshmallow."

title: Takeover of Flushing Hospital Leads to a Review
description: The takeover of one of the oldest hospitals in New York City has escalated into a battle over health care in Queens, prompting allegations of conflicts of interest involving some of the hospital's trustees and drawing the attention of New York State's Attorney General.

title: Ethiopians Return, Glad to Help Build a New Land
description: After two decades of Marxist rule and civil war that have left the economy in ruins, a handful of Ethiopians have returned here from exile to help build a new government in a nation that has never had a democratic tradition.

title: Bridge
description: Seven years ago, Fred Stewart and Steve Weinstein failed to win the prestigious Cavendish Invitational Pairs by the equivalent of a couple of overtricks. During the past weekend they made up for that disappointment, winning by 690 imps, one of the biggest margins ever.

title: Accord Returns U.N. Troops to Mostar
description: United Nations patrols returned cautiously to the battle-scarred streets of Mostar this afternoon, after United Nations officers and rival commanders announced another cease-fire aimed at ending four days of fighting between Croats and Bosnian Muslims.

title: Wilder's 'Wilder' Is to Close
description: "Wilder, Wilder, Wilder," three short plays written by Thornton Wilder and directed by Edward Berkeley, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Circle in the Square Theater. The Sunday matinee will be the 44th performance.

title: Clinton Supports Creating Fund Designated Solely to Cut Deficit
description: Responding to accusations by Ross Perot and Republicans that he is just another tax-and-spend Democrat, President Clinton yesterday endorsed a proposal to require that all the money raised by tax increases in his new budget be used solely to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: NERVE CELLS TIED TO IMMUNE SYSTEM
description: Scientists have found the first evidence of an anatomical connection between the nervous system and the immune system.

title: Nugget Wins Improved Player Award
description: CHRIS JACKSON of the Denver Nuggets yesterday was voted the National Basketball Association's Most Improved Player Award for 1993.

title: Details Offered On Alternative To Westway
description: Details of a proposed "boutique" boulevard, flanked by a walkway and bike path along the Hudson River, have been completed by the New York State Transportation Department as the latest alternative to Westway, the abandoned project that was supposed to replace the razed West Side Highway between the Battery and 59th Street.

title: Vishay Intertechnology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,427,000, or 7 cents a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.The latest quarter also included a restructuring charge of $ 1,510,000 related to reduction of overhead personnel in the company's French operations as a result of ''the business climate in France.'' The company said the charge will be offset by the savings resulting from the restructuring by the end of the year.The latest quarter also included a charge of $ 300,000 for adoption of SFAS 106, and a currency loss of $ 600,000. It also included $ 2 million in income that the company said is the minimum amount it will receive in payment for lost profits from a business interruption insurance claim.The company said that the increase in sales in the latest quarter resulted from the acquisition of Roederstein GmbH on Jan. 1, 1993, which the company said had ''strong'' earnings.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS SELLING STAKE IN TV PARTS COMPANY
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. has agreed in principle to sell its stake in a company that produces television glass parts to its venture partner, the Nippon Electric Glass Company of Japan, for $100 million. Owens-Illinois would still play a role in the management of OI-NEG TV Products Inc. and would continue to be represented on its board. Owens-Illinois, based in Toledo, Ohio, has earmarked the sale's proceeds to reduce debt and for general corporate purposes.

title: No Headline
description: "I had my own stereotypes about Marine Corps colonels, and I assumed because of the life style he chose, he would have certain political views. Knowing what I know now I wish I had had more faith in my father and talked to him a long time ago." -- SCOTT PECK, who told his father of his homosexuality just days before the colonel's Congressional testimony. [ A19:1. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some of ALEXANDER JULIAN'S most recent men's wear creations have been seen on collegiate and professional basketball courts rather than fashion runways, and seem somehow connected to winning plays.

title: Chairman Is Hopeful At Kodak
description: Kay R. Whitmore, the embattled chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company, told shareholders yesterday that Kodak would have a "solid earnings increase" this year and predicted that next year, earnings per share would set a record.

title: Breaking a Stereotype, More Men Are Being Hired as Nannies
description: ON Monday night, "Murphy Brown" will close out its season with an episode celebrating the first birthday of Murphy's son. No one can take more pride in little Avery's progress than his nanny, the former house painter Eldin. Murphy spent weeks trying to find a suitable person to take care of her baby before discovering the perfect nanny: a sensitive, playful, caring man.

title: Even a One-Man Staff Needs a Little Help
description: Dwight Gooden needed the eight other Mets tonight. He throws a shutout about every other start, but some of Gooden's pitches spun incorrectly here in the Missouri rain, and -- as is typical -- his teammates could not bail him out.

title: G.E. Deal Will Help Save GPA
description: GPA Group P.L.C. said late today that it had reached a deal under which the General Electric Company will help the giant aircraft-leasing company avert financial collapse. As part of the deal, G.E. would acquire 45 planes from GPA for $1.35 billion.

title: Federated Net Aided By Controls
description: The first-quarter results issued yesterday by Federated Department Stores Inc. demonstrated that attention to cost control could mitigate the impact of high markdowns and weak sales.

title: Woman in the News; A 'Full-Time Volunteer': Carol Ann Gresser
description: To stand at the center of contentious issues, take time with deliberations and live with a "burdensome conscience," as Carol A. Gresser once described her own, is to sometimes court two different perceptions. Often regarded as a classic swing voter on New York City's Board of Education, Mrs. Gresser, in her three years as a board member from Queens, has been described, by turns, as thoughtful and Machiavellian.

title: SAGASCO MAKES HOSTILE BID FOR MAGELLAN PETROLEUM
description: Shares of the Magellan Petroleum Corporation jumped yesterday after Sagasco Holdings Ltd. said it was making a hostile bid to buy the company for $37 million. Arthur B. O'Donnell, vice president of Magellan Petroleum, based in Hartford, said the company's board would meet to discuss the plan. Sagasco, of Adelaide, South Australia, has offered $1.50 a share for the 24.4 million shares Magellan Petroleum has outstanding, according to the plan filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Magellan Petroleum shares rose 43.75 cents, to $1.375, on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Roy J. Karrell; Cosmetics Entrepreneur, 44
description: Roy J. Karrell, who founded a cosmetics company, died Monday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 44.

title: Marka T. duPont, 82, Health and Art Patron
description: Marka Truesdale duPont, a patron of mental-health groups and the performing arts, died Tuesday at her home in Wilmington, Del. She was 82.

title: Intergroup Healthcare (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knicks Collapse, Catch a Breath, Then Charge
description: After a tremendous game and a tremendous comeback, the Knicks escaped with another memorable victory.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the cocaine trade in Jackson Heights and Elmhurst, Queens, misstated the composition of the borough's Hispanic population. Puerto Ricans are the largest Hispanic group in Queens; Colombians are the largest group of Hispanic immigrants.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Frederick E. Lane, 84, Is Dead; Doctor Helped Found 2 Hospitals
description: Frederick E. Lane, a physician, hospital administrator and charity fund-raiser, died on Tuesday at his home in Plandome Manor, L.I. He was 84.

title: Horwitz Gives Himself An Error on the Play
description: Bobby Bonilla has been blamed, rightly or wrongly, for a lot of things. Today, though, someone else stepped forward to take the blame for one of the more controversial moments in the right fielder's tenure in New York.

title: A PRICE RISE FANS INFLATION CONCERN
description: An unexpected surge in wholesale prices last month, the latest of a string of higher price reports, left many economists and investors wondering whether the inflation genie was starting to slip out of the bottle.

title: Books of The Times; Taking the Frivolity of Games Seriously Indeed
description: Game Over How Nintendo Zapped an American Industry, Captured Your Dollars and Enslaved Your Children By David Sheff 445 pages. Random House. $25.

title: When Managed Care Manages Psychotherapy; Self-Insurance Scams
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Terrorism From Colombia
description: Fourteen months have passed since Colombian drug lords murdered Manuel de Dios Unanue in New York City for writing muckraking stories about the drug trade. As time slipped by, anguished friends and family asserted that police were dragging their feet because Mr. de Dios was from the Spanish-language press and little known to the English-speaking audience.

title: Reno Urges Senate to Curb Anti-Abortion Violence
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today urged Congress to move swiftly to make violence or threats against abortion providers and women seeking abortions a Federal crime.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the fraud and bribery trial of Robert A. Altman misstated the disposition of a Federal money-laundering charge against Dildar Rizvi, a key prosecution witness. The Government has agreed to dismiss the case against Mr. Rizvi in return for his cooperation with the prosecution.

title: We Need Student Loan Reform, and Soon
description: To the Editor:

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Design Books Reveal Ambivalence on Glamour
description: DESIGN books in the 1980's packaged rich and exotic rooms for the American coffee table, and the nation's style quotient soared. But a new ambivalence about glamour emerges from this spring's range of books. At one end is a volume of designer-name decorating (no instructions included), and at the other is an anti-decorating treatise complete with how-to details and an attitude.

title: Dow Climbs by 13.56 to a Record 3,482.31
description: Shrugging off discouraging news on producer prices and a decline in the bond market, traders bid up the stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, pushing it to a record 3,482.31.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Tuesday about "Martyrs' Day: Chronicle of a Small War," by Michael Kelly, referred incorrectly to another author. He was A. J. Liebling.

title: Hyatt Account Goes To BBDO New York
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation of Chicago said yesterday that it had selected BBDO New York to handle its $25 million account, which had been at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. of Boston. Hyatt and Hill, Holliday said in November that they would end their five-year relationship because of "fundamental, philosophical disagreements over the future direction of the national advertising."

title: N.C.A.A. Looks for Another Schultz
description: Presented with Dick Schultz's sudden resignation on Tuesday as executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the responsibilities that come with the end of the academic year, officials responsible for finding a successor are not expected to begin work until next week.

title: Have Your Plate and Wear It, Too
description: THE woman who likes Gianni Versace's flashy clothes, printed with gold chains or medallions against a richly colored background, can now have porcelain dishes to match.

title: Psychoanalyst and Lawyer Duel Over Nuances at a Libel Trial
description: Jeffrey M. Masson's voice, sometimes low and throaty, other times rising in excited falsetto, filled a Federal courtroom here today as jurors considered the nuance, context and vocabulary of five disputed quotations that are at the heart of his libel suit against Janet Malcolm and The New Yorker magazine.

title: Report Calls Simple Test Effective In Reducing Colon Cancer Deaths
description: After decades of debate and inconclusive findings, a major new study has shown that a yearly test can significantly reduce deaths from colorectal cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths among Americans.

title: Why Has New York City Just Recognized Small Businesses?; A Role in Exports
description: To the Editor:

title: Rostenkowski Urges Clinton To Seek Support 'Out There'
description: As he struggled to forge the tax legislation that is the core of President Clinton's economic program, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested today that the President needed to generate more enthusiasm in the country for his plan if he hoped to get it enacted.

title: Speared, and Still Alive to Tell About It
description: A major problem with having an eight-foot aluminum javelin lodged in your neck is that you can't fit into a helicopter with it. This is the predicament in which Jeremy Campbell, a 15-year-old sophomore high school student, found himself Monday afternoon.

title: Polk Audio (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
